sect1.title: 49 Francisella*

para.phrase: ELIZABETH A. DIETRICH AND JEANNINE M. PETERSEN

sect1.para: Francisella tularensis is the causative agent of tularemia, an acute and fatal illness in animals and humans. Human infections caused by F. tularensis occur via arthropod bite, handling of infected animals, inhalation of infectious aerosols, and ingestion of contaminated food or water. F. tularensis is highly infectious, with 10 organisms being sufficient to cause illness, and therefore poses a serious risk for laboratory-acquired infections. It has been studied as a potential biological weapon and is one of six bacterial agents classified by the United States government as Tier 1 select agents, considered to present the greatest risk of deliberate misuse with the most significant potential for mass casualties or devastating effects to the economy, critical infrastructure, or public confidence.

Within the genusFrancisella, F. tularensis is joined by several lesser-known Francisella species which are largely environmental organisms. F. novicida, F. philomiragia, F. hispaniensis, and F. opportunistica cause rare opportunistic infections in immunocompromised individuals. Other Francisella species include pathogens of aquatic organisms, environmental bacteria isolated from aquatic environments, and tick endosymbionts.

sect2.title: TAXONOMY
sect2.para: The familyFrancisellaceae belongs to the order Thiotrichales and the gamma subclass of proteobacteria. The family currently consists of three genera: Francisella, Allofrancisella, and Pseudofrancisella. Allofrancisella and Pseudofrancisella spp. are environmental organisms that have not been associated with disease and are not considered further in this chapter (1, 2). Several publications have reviewed the history and descriptions of members of the genus Francisella (3–5). The genus currently consists of F. tularensis, F. novicida, F. philomiragia, F. hispaniensis, F. opportunistica, F. noatunensis, F. orientalis, F. halioticida, F. salimarina, and F. persica, as well as unclassified Francisella spp. (https://www.bacterio.net/genus/francisella).

F. tularensis, the species of main clinical significance, is the causative agent of tularemia, a zoonosis affecting humans and a wide range of animals. The bacterium was first isolated from squirrels suffering a “plague-like” illness in Tulare County, California. Three subspecies of F. tularensis, F. tularensis subsp. tularensis (type A), F. tularensis subsp. holarctica (type B), and F. tularensis subsp. mediasiatica, are recognized, with ≥99.2% average nucleotide identity (ANI) across 1.1 Mb of genome sequence (6).

F. novicida and F. philomiragia were originally isolated from saltwater sources and are genetically, biochemically, and serologically distinct from F. tularensis, in addition to having reduced virulence (6–8). F. philomiragia is relatively phylogenetically distant from F. tularensis, and the two genomes display <83% ANI (5, 9). A high degree of genetic similarity exists between F. novicida and F. tularensis, and on this basis, F. novicida was proposed as a fourth subspecies of F. tularensis (10, 11). Whole-genome comparisons, however, provide evidence that F. novicida and F. tularensis evolved as two distinct population lineages, consistent with F. novicida and F. tularensis being two separate species (6, 7, 12). Clinical and ecological differences between F. tularensis and F. novicida also indicate that the two represent distinct species (7, 12) (see “Epidemiology and Transmission” and “Clinical Significance” below).

F. hispaniensis is a rare opportunistic pathogen that has been isolated from human cases in Spain, Australia, and China (11, 13–16). F. hispaniensis genomes show approximately 90% ANI with genomes of both F. tularensis and F. novicida and approximately 83% ANI with F. philomiragia (9). F. opportunistica has been isolated in culture from three immunocompromised patients in the United States and displays approximately 87% ANI to F. tularensis, F. novicida, and F. hispaniensis genomes (17).

F. noatunensis, F. orientalis, and F. halioticida are pathogens of saltwater fish species and giant abalone (18–20). These species cluster phylogenetically with F. philomiragia (5). Other isolates have been derived from aquatic sources, including seawater and cooling towers (9, 21). F. persica, an endosymbiont of ticks, was formerly known as Wolbachia persica, but was reassigned to the genus Francisella based on sequence analysis (22). The F. persica genome has a reduced gene content, consistent with its status as an endosymbiont (9, 22). Other Francisella-like endosymbionts have been identified in a variety of tick species by sequence analysis but have not been cultured or assigned formal taxonomic status (3, 23).

table.title: TABLE 1 Differentiation of F. tularensis from similar Gram-negative bacteriaa

sect2.para: a+, greater than or equal to 90% positive; −, less than or equal to 10% positive; V, variable (11 to 89% positive); ccb, coccobacilli.
bHaemophilus spp. requiring X and V factors or V factor only.

sect2.title: DESCRIPTION OF THE GENUS
sect2.para: Francisella spp. are tiny Gram-negative coccobacilli which range in size from 0.2 to 1.7 μm. Features distinguishing Francisella from similar genera are shown in Table 1. Members of the genus take up Gram counterstain (safranin) poorly; they are strict aerobes, urease negative, nonmotile, and non-spore forming, and they metabolize a limited number of carbohydrates (Table 2). Only a few sugars (glucose, maltose, sucrose, and glycerol) are utilized by most members of the genus. Acid is produced without gas. Unique cellular fatty acids are associated with the genus (3, 10). For most species, in vitro growth is enhanced by cysteine supplementation (3). A few key differences separate species of the genus Francisella, including growth in nutrient broth with 6% NaCl, optimum growth temperatures, and sugar utilization (Table 2). Cultured members of the genus share >95% sequence identity within their 16S rRNA genes (3, 9). Genomes of all clinically relevant members of the genus share >80% ANI, although some environmental species are more distantly related. Genomes of F. tularensis strains within all three subspecies share ANI of >99%. ANI between F. tularensis and F. novicida genomes is approximately 97 to 98% (9, 17).

F. tularensis is the most virulent Francisella species in mammals. In laboratory mice inoculated subcutaneously or intradermally, a 50% lethal dose (LD50) of only 1 to 10 cells is observed for F. tularensis, compared with LD50s ranging from 10 to 107 cells for F. novicida (7). F. philomiragia has an LD50 of 3.45 × 103 cells when inoculated intranasally into mice (24). Levels of virulence also differ between F. tularensis subspecies; F. tularensis subsp. tularensis displays an LD100 of <10 cells when inoculated subcutaneously into rabbits, compared to an LD100 of 109 cells for F. tularensis subsp. holarctica (25).

AllFrancisella genomes are composed of a single chromosome, which in most cases is ~1.9 Mb with a GC content of ~32%. Whole-genome analyses indicate that F. tularensis contains very few unique genes in comparison to other members of the genus, including F. novicida (5). One distinguishing feature of the F. tularensis genome compared to other Francisella genomes is duplication of the Francisella pathogenicity island, which encodes an atypical type VI secretion system required for intracellular growth and virulence (26). In all other Francisella genomes sequenced to date, this pathogenicity island is present only in a single copy (9, 17).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: F. tularensis has been recovered primarily in the Northern Hemisphere, with a few reports of F. tularensis subsp. holarctica in Australia (27, 28) (Table 3). The distribution of the subspecies varies throughout the Northern Hemisphere (4, 23, 29, 30). Infections caused by F. tularensis subsp. holarctica occur throughout the Northern Hemisphere, whereas F. tularensis subsp. tularensis is found only in North America. F. tularensis subsp. mediasiatica has been found only in regions of central Asia and Russia (31). Within the United States, the F. tularensis subsp. tularensis A1 (also called A.I) subpopulation predominates in the eastern half of the country, whereas the A2 (A.II) subpopulation appears to be restricted to the western half (32–34).

Despite the broad geographic distribution ofF. tularensis, overall disease occurrence is suspected to be low (4). Foci of endemicity, where incidence may be higher, have long been documented in regions of Russia and Kazakhstan, as well as Finland, Sweden, and the United States (4, 30, 35). In the United States, the incidence of tularemia is approximately 200 cases each year; detailed statistics are available at http://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/statistics. All states except Hawaii have reported cases. Tularemia is most commonly reported in the south-central states of Missouri, Arkansas, Kansas, and Oklahoma. In the European Union, an average of approximately 800 cases of tularemia was reported annually from 2012 to 2019 (36). Reported cases by country in the European Union can be found at https://ecdc.europa.eu/en/tularaemia/surveillance-and-disease-data/disease-data-atlas.

Tularemia in humans is predominantly a rural disease, and urban cases are rare. Most cases of tularemia occur in the summer months, with patients acquiringF. tularensis infection from tick or deerfly bites or from contact with infected animals (e.g., by skinning rabbits) (4). Inhalation of an infective aerosol during landscaping, particularly when mowing over dead rabbits, and contact with infected cats are also potential sources of infection (37, 38). Dogs may carry F. tularensis in their mouths or on their fur, with or without clinical signs, posing a risk to owners who engage in close facial contact (39). Tularemia is more commonly reported in males than in females, possibly due to more frequent exposure through hunting and landscaping. Tularemia cases are largely sporadic, and outbreaks of tularemia are rare.

F. tularensis is a zoonotic pathogen, capable of infecting a large variety of animal species. The bacterium has been isolated from vertebrates, including mammals, amphibians, and birds, as well as from invertebrate arthropods (23, 40). The arthropod vectors most commonly associated with transmission of tularemia to humans in the United States are ticks (Dermacentor spp. and Amblyomma americanum) and deerflies (Chrysops spp.) (41). In Sweden and Finland, mosquitoes are the primary arthropod associated with transmission of F. tularensis (41, 42). Among vertebrates, F. tularensis is most commonly associated with rodents and other mammals, particularly hares and rabbits. In both vertebrates and invertebrates, infection with F. tularensis can be lethal.

sect2.para: a Human infections documented in the published literature.

In contrast toF. tularensis, F. novicida and F. philomiragia do not appear to circulate in animal or arthropod hosts. Arthropods infected with F. novicida or F. philomiragia have never been identified. F. philomiragia has been isolated from a muskrat and from a dog (43, 44). Transmission of F. novicida and F. philomiragia to humans appears to be associated with proximity to or contact with saltwater sources, such as near-drowning (8, 45). One outbreak of F. novicida disease in humans has been reported. This outbreak occurred among inmates of a correctional facility and was associated with consumption of ice from outdoor ice machines (46).

Most isolates ofF. novicida are from North America, although one case has been reported in Thailand (15, 47). Similarly, most isolates of F. philomiragia have been from North America; however, isolates have also been reported from France, Switzerland, Turkey, and Australia (8, 10, 15, 48–50).

sect1.title: F. tularensis
sect1.para: Tularemia has been known historically by several synonyms, such as rabbit fever, deerfly fever, market men’s disease, glandular type of tick fever, Ohara’s or yato-byo disease, and water rat trappers’ disease, attesting to the variety of clinical presentations, the infectious agent’s ubiquitous presence in nature, and the means by which humans may acquire the infection.

The clinical spectrum of tularemia depends on the mode of transmission, the virulence of the infecting strain, the immune status of the host, and timely diagnosis and treatment (51). Tularemia can be misdiagnosed, since the disease is rare and its symptoms are not unique; a sudden onset of chills, fever, headache, and generalized malaise characterizes the onset of illness. The incubation period is typically 3 to 5 days, but it can range from 1 to 21 days (51). Disease presentation (signs and symptoms) correlates with the route of bacterial entry. All forms of tularemia are accompanied by fever, and most are also associated with lymphadenopathy (51). The most common clinical form of tularemia is ulceroglandular disease (45 to 80% of the reported cases), where the portal of entry is via an infective arthropod bite or other inoculation through the skin barrier. Glandular tularemia is similar to ulceroglandular disease but lacks the ulcerated site of infection. Oculoglandular tularemia occurs when the conjunctiva is the initial site of infection. Oropharyngeal tularemia occurs from ingestion of contaminated water or food and is characterized by pharyngeal lymphadenopathy. Pneumonic tularemia follows direct inhalation of the organism and is considered the most severe form of the disease. Typhoidal tularemia lacks localized signs, making it the most difficult form to recognize. For all forms, if untreated, bacterial dissemination from the primary site of infection can lead to secondary clinical presentations, such as sepsis or pneumonia.

The severity of infection can range from mild and self-limiting to fatal and is largely dependent on the infecting strain. Little or no tularemia-related mortality is reported in Europe and Asia, where onlyF. tularensis subsp. holarctica causes tularemia (30). In comparison, estimates of mortality in the United States, where both F. tularensis subsp. tularensis and F. tularensis subsp. holarctica are present, range from 2 to 9% (52, 53). Among culture-confirmed human cases in the United States, infections due to strains of F. tularensis subsp. tularensis in the A1 subpopulation result in higher mortality than infections caused by F. tularensis subsp. tularensis A2 strains or F. tularensis subsp. holarctica (32, 34).

The third subspecies ofF. tularensis, F. tularensis subsp. mediasiatica, has been isolated only from regions of Russia and Central Asia, and no human illness due to this subspecies has been described (31).

sect1.title: F. novicida and F. philomiragia
sect1.para: Human infections caused byF. novicida and F. philomiragia are rare, as these species primarily infect patients with underlying immune compromising conditions. Healthy individuals present with mild illness (regional lymphadenopathy). Patients with immunocompromising conditions, primarily underlying liver disease, present with fevers, with F. novicida isolated from blood samples (46). F. novicida has also been associated with near-drowning incidents (45).

Similarly, fewF. philomiragia infections have been described (54). Most cases have involved either a host with an impaired physical barrier to infection (near-drowning) or an impaired immunologic defense system (most commonly chronic granulomatous disease).

sect1.title: Other Francisella Species
sect1.para: Very few human cases have been reported with otherFrancisella species. Most cases of F. hispaniensis infection have been associated with exposure to brackish or saltwater (14–16). The isolate from the first case was originally described as “novicida-like” but has subsequently been reclassified as F. hispaniensis (9, 15). F. opportunistica was isolated from the blood or cerebrospinal fluid of three patients in the United States, all with immune compromising conditions but with no recognized common exposure (17, 55). Another novel Francisella sp. was isolated in 2011 from a cutaneous lesion of a patient in the United States (56).

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Clinical laboratories should be aware of the sentinel-level clinical microbiology laboratory guidelines as outlined by the American Society for Microbiology (https://asm.org/Articles/Policy/Laboratory-Response-Network-LRN-Sentinel-Level-C). In the United States, F. tularensis is classified as a Tier 1 select agent (see chapter 16 of this Manual). In the European Union and Russia, F. tularensis is classified as belonging to the very-high-threat group and group 1, respectively (57). To receive or possess F. tularensis strains in the United States, laboratories must be registered with the Federal Select Agent Program (http://www.selectagents.gov). Clinical laboratories that do not store confirmed select agents are exempt from the registration requirement. Unregistered laboratories may perform testing for select agents as long as the laboratory destroys or transfers to a registered laboratory any select agent (including clinical samples the isolate was derived from) within 7 days after organism identification. F. novicida isolates (also referred to as F. tularensis subsp. novicida) are exempt from select agent regulations; see the list of excluded strains at https://www.selectagents.gov/sat/exclusions/hhs.htm.

The choice of specimen for direct detection is generally dependent on the form of clinical illness (51). Whole blood is an acceptable specimen for all clinical forms of tularemia, although this sample lacks sensitivity in the early stages of disease progression. Bronchial and tracheal washes or aspirates, transthoracic lung aspirates, and pleural fluid (if effusions are present) are appropriate specimens for pneumonic tularemia. Swabs of visible lesions are most used for diagnosis of ulceroglandular, oculoglandular, and oropharyngeal tularemia. Aspirates from lymph nodes can be used for diagnosis of ulceroglandular, glandular, and oropharyngeal tularemia. For testing of necropsied materials from animals, appropriate samples include lymph node, lung, liver, and spleen tissues and bone marrow.

For specimens to be tested by culture, it is important, where possible, to decontaminate the surface area prior to specimen collection. Contamination of the sample with normal microbiota could interfere with the interpretation of culture results. To minimize loss of viability, specimens should be delivered to the clinical laboratory promptly for testing. Freezing of samples is not recommended because of the lysis of live bacteria upon thawing, unless in a preservative environment, such as tissue specimens or glycerol-containing solutions.F. tularensis should remain viable for 7 days at ambient room temperature when stored in Amies medium (58). ESwabs (COPAN Diagnostics, Murrieta, CA) have not been specifically tested for use with F. tularensis but may be suitable for transport, as they are based on Amies medium. Modified Stuart medium and saline are inadequate for keeping F. tularensis viable during transport (58).

For indirect detection, serum is a standard specimen for serologic diagnosis of all forms of illness. Separation from blood should take place as soon as possible. Frozen serum samples can often be accepted for serologic testing.

sect1.title: Laboratory Safety Issues for Handling of F. tularensis Cultures
sect1.para: Personnel handling diagnostic cultures ofF. tularensis are at increased risk for infection. Due to the extremely low infectious dose for F. tularensis, tularemia has historically been one of the most reported laboratory-associated bacterial infections, primarily when safeguards such as biological safety cabinets and personal protective equipment are not used (59, 60). Rare laboratory infections have been reported in recent decades (61–63). BSL-2 practices, containment equipment, and facilities are recommended for initial processing of clinical specimens where F. tularensis is suspected. BSL-3 practices, containment equipment, and facilities are recommended for all manipulations of suspect cultures, including preparatory work for identification systems (64). Due to the high concentration of organisms, manipulation of cultures presents the greatest risk to laboratory workers (60). Management options for laboratorians who have worked with F. tularensis without appropriate precautions include fever watch or antibiotic prophylaxis. Factors to consider include the nature of the exposure, incubation period, and level of concern. More guidance is available at https://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/laboratoryexposure/index.html. Laboratories should consider developing policies that encourage physicians to alert the laboratory if a diagnosis of tularemia is expected.

sect1.title: Microscopy
sect1.para: Under microscopic examination of Gram-stained specimens,Francisella cells are single, tiny, and pleomorphic. They counterstain faintly with safranin and can easily be overlooked (Fig. 1). F. tularensis cells are smaller than those of Haemophilus spp. Basic fuchsin counterstains F. tularensis better than safranin. Gram staining of clinical specimens is usually of limited diagnostic value. F. tularensis should be included in the clinical laboratory differential if very small, faintly staining Gram-negative coccobacilli are seen.

sect1.title: Antigen Detection
sect1.para: Immunohistochemical staining using a monoclonal antibody directed against the lipopolysaccharide has been used to visualizeF. tularensis in formalin-fixed tissues (65). In the United States, direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) testing of isolates may be available in reference laboratories within the Laboratory Response Network (LRN). DFA staining involves the use of a fluorescein isothiocyanate-labeled hyperimmune rabbit polyclonal antibody directed against whole, killed F. tularensis cells. The DFA reagent does not cross-react with F. novicida or F. philomiragia.

figure.title: Figure 1 Gram stain of F. tularensis. Courtesy of the CDC Public Health Image Library (Larry Stauffer, Oregon State Public Health Laboratory).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Because of the relative rarity of human tularemia, evaluation of molecular diagnostics with clinical specimens has been limited. Real-time nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) assays using 5′ hydrolysis (TaqMan) probes have been applied to detectF. tularensis DNA in clinical specimens (66–70). Real-time NAAT assays for detection of F. tularensis in blood specimens and suspect cultures are available in LRN reference laboratories in the United States. Tularemia can also be detected by sequencing methods, including either targeted (typically 16S rRNA gene) or shotgun sequencing methods (71). One test that shows promise is pathogen identification by shotgun metagenomics, which is based on untargeted next-generation sequencing (NGS), or massive parallel sequencing of the genomic content of a clinical specimen. F. tularensis has been reported to be detected by one such test performed on plasma (72). However, these methods have not been fully evaluated for Francisella species, and diagnoses should be confirmed by reference methods whenever possible.

A limitation of some nucleic acid-based diagnostics forF. tularensis is the inability to discriminate F. tularensis from F. novicida, due to their high degree of genetic relatedness. Real-time NAAT assays using 5′ hydrolysis (TaqMan) probes may demonstrate cross-reaction between F. tularensis and F. novicida (67). Additionally, analysis of only the 16S rRNA gene sequence is usually insufficient to discriminate F. tularensis from F. novicida (46, 73). While this may not be significant for patient management, the correct identification of species has biothreat, epidemiologic, and public health importance.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: F. tularensis is slow growing and fastidious; it is auxotrophic for cysteine and as such requires an exogenous source of cysteine to grow well on artificial medium. CO2 neither impedes nor is required for growth. F. tularensis will grow on several media common to clinical laboratories, including chocolate agar (CA) (Fig. 2A), buffered charcoal-yeast extract agar (BCYE), and Thayer-Martin agar. It also grows in thioglycolate broth, although growth in broth is not recommended in clinical laboratories due to the increased risk of exposure via aerosolization. A specialized medium, cystine heart agar supplemented with 9% chocolatized sheep blood (CHAB), may be used for the growth of F. tularensis in reference laboratories (51). F. tularensis grows well and displays distinctive colony morphology on CHAB, which can aid in identification (Fig. 2B). As F. tularensis grows slowly, with a 60-minute generation time, good growth is obtained by incubation for 48 hours or longer. Suspect cultures should be incubated aerobically at 35 to 37°C and observed daily for up to 14 days.

When supplemented with 1 to 2% IsoVitaleX (which contains cysteine and other supplements), general bacteriological media (tryptic soy broth and Mueller-Hinton broth) can also support growth ofF. tularensis. F. tularensis grows poorly or not at all on media lacking cysteine, such as sheep blood agar. Nutritionally enriched specimens, such as blood or tissue, provide an intrinsic source of cysteine that may initially permit F. tularensis growth on general bacteriological media. Upon subculture, viability of F. tularensis is lost as exogenous compounds are depleted, unless subculture is propagated on cysteine-supplemented medium.

Clinical samples from normally sterile sites can be plated on nonselective agars that support growth ofF. tularensis. Care should be taken not to permit laboratory contamination of F. tularensis isolates, as some environmental bacteria rapidly outcompete and inhibit the growth of F. tularensis on nonselective media (74). Clinical specimens obtained from nonsterile sites or autopsy and environmental sources should be plated on antibiotic-containing media. Incorporation of an antibiotic supplement (7.5 mg/liter of colistin, 2.5 mg/liter of amphotericin, 0.5 mg/liter of lincomycin, 4.0 mg/liter of trimethoprim, and 10 mg/liter of ampicillin) into the medium prevents other organisms from overwhelming F. tularensis (74). Commercially available antibiotic-containing media that support growth of F. tularensis include improved Thayer-Martin agar and BCYE selective agar containing polymyxin B, anisomycin, and vancomycin.

Specimens for culture should be taken based on clinical presentation and before administration of antibiotics. Fresh clinical material that is likely to contain high concentrations ofF. tularensis organisms, such as ulcer and wound specimens and reticuloendothelial tissue (liver, spleen, or affected lymph node tissue), is inoculated directly onto an agar plate using a sample-laden swab or loop. Larger inocula are necessary for the recovery of F. tularensis from specimens that contain a lower concentration of the organisms, such as blood, pharyngeal washes, bronchial wash fluids, and pleural fluids. Whole blood should be directly inoculated into aerobic blood culture bottles and incubated on continuous monitoring systems (51), with subsequent culture of blood culture-positive specimens on agar. Blood culture bottles should be incubated for 5 to 7 days to allow growth of F. tularensis. In a review of 30 cases of F. tularensis bacteremia, ~50% of the isolations utilized the BACTEC system (75).

figure.title: Figure 2 F. tularensis on CA (A) and cystine heart agar supplemented with 9% chocolatized sheep blood (CHAB) (B) after 72 and 48 hours of growth, respectively. (Panel A is courtesy of the CDC Public Health Image Library [Larry Stauffer, Oregon State Public Health Laboratory].)

sect2.para: F. novicida, F. philomiragia, and F. hispaniensis grow faster than F. tularensis and are less fastidious. Cysteine supplementation enhances but is not required for growth (3, 14).

sect2.title: IDENTIFICATION
sect2.para: Because of the rarity as well as the sporadic nature of most tularemia cases, the organism is often not suspected and is therefore not easily identified when it is cultured. The isolation of a very tiny, poorly counterstaining, slow-growing Gram-negative coccobacillus (Fig. 1) that produces 1- to 2-mm, gray or gray-white colonies on CA after 48 hours, scant to no growth on blood agar, and no growth on MacConkey agar should raise suspicion of F. tularensis. All testing on isolates suspected as being F. tularensis should be performed at a minimum within a biosafety cabinet until F. tularensis is ruled out. F. tularensis is oxidase negative, weakly catalase positive, β-lactamase positive, X and V or satellite growth negative, and urease negative. Table 1 lists characteristics that can help differentiate F. tularensis from other similar Gram-negative organisms. One of the most common misidentifications of F. tularensis in culture is Haemophilus influenzae, which can be differentiated from F. tularensis based on XV or satellite tests. If F. tularensis is suspected based on these results, the isolate should be sent to a reference laboratory that can confirm (or rule out) its identification as F. tularensis. In the United States, all states have at least one LRN reference laboratory that can confirm the identification of bacterial select agents, including F. tularensis. More information is available at http://www.emergency.cdc.gov/lrn.

On CA, BCYE, and Thayer-Martin agar after 48 h at 37°C,F. tularensis colonies are ~1 mm, white to gray in color, and smooth and opaque with an entire margin (Fig. 2A). The colony morphology of F. tularensis is most distinctive when grown on CHAB; after 48 h at 37°C, F. tularensis colonies are 1 to 2 mm, raised, shiny, green, and opalescent (Fig. 2B). F. novicida and F. philomiragia grow more robustly than F. tularensis (Table 2), and colonies of F. philomiragia are mucoid.

Isolates can be identified asF. tularensis using antigen or molecular detection methods, including DFA detection, NAAT, or sequencing. DFA can differentiate F. novicida from F. tularensis. Polyclonal antibodies to whole killed F. tularensis cells used in this test react poorly or not at all with F. novicida due to differences in the O antigens of the lipopolysaccharides of the two organisms (51, 76).

NAAT methods can also be used for identification of suspect cultures (67, 73, 77). A NAAT-based system has been cleared by the FDA for detection of biothreat agents including F. tularensis (https://www.biofiredefense.com/products/biofire-filmarray-biosurveillance-system/#Warrior). However, this system is not commercially available. As mentioned above, some F. tularensis NAAT assays cross-react with F. novicida. Therefore, it may be important to rule out F. novicida or other Francisella species as the cause of infection, particularly in areas where tularemia has not been previously reported. 16S rRNA gene sequencing can provide a genus-level identification; isolates identified by this method should be considered Francisella species and referred to an LRN reference laboratory for F. tularensis-specific testing.

Commercial biochemical identification systems are not recommended for the diagnosis ofF. tularensis because of the possibility of misidentification and the potential for generating infectious aerosols (51). F. tularensis may be misidentified as H. influenzae or Aggregatibacter (see ASM sentinel-level clinical laboratory guidelines at https://asm.org/Articles/Policy/Laboratory-Response-Network-LRN-Sentinel-Level-C). Misidentification is largely due to a lack of biochemical reactivity by F. tularensis, slow growth, and the limited number of strains used in the development of databases. Misidentification of both F. novicida and F. hispaniensis as F. tularensis using these systems in clinical laboratory settings has been described (14, 45). Other organisms, such as Veillonella, Pseudomonas, and Paenibacillus spp., have also been misidentified as F. tularensis by these systems, leading to unnecessary biosafety and biosecurity concerns (78–80).

Matrix-assisted laser desorption ionization–time of flight (MALDI-TOF) mass spectrometry (MS) has been used for identification and differentiation ofFrancisella strains in research and reference laboratories (81–85). However, as with biochemical systems, Francisella species may not be present in available commercial databases, and use of commercial MALDI-TOF MS systems is likely to result in no reliable identification in the clinical laboratory (83). A MALDI-TOF MS database containing F. tularensis for in vitro diagnostic use is available with special security clearance for use with the Bruker Biotyper instrument, but this database still requires in-house supplementation to attain species-level identifications (82, 86). For the bioMérieux VITEK MS system, F. tularensis is available only in the database labeled for research use only (83). Thus, this method is currently of limited utility in clinical laboratories. Safety considerations in target preparation for MALDI-TOF MS analysis, including preparation in a biosafety cabinet, must also be considered. An ethanol-formic acid tube extraction procedure inactivates F. tularensis and other select agents more reliably than direct colony or on-plate formic acid extraction (83, 87).

Potential indications of misidentification by automated systems (biochemical, MALDI-TOF MS) include a low probability or confidence value and/or an identification of a pathogen inconsistent with the clinical or microbiological picture. Results from automated identification systems should be analyzed critically in the clinical laboratory, taking into consideration the reliability of these systems for accurate identification of select agents, slow-growing, and/or rare organisms along with Gram stain characteristics, colony morphology, rate of growth, and culture conditions. A high level of suspicion by clinical microbiologists is essential for accurate and timely diagnosis of tularemia and to prevent laboratory-acquired infections.

sect2.title: TYPING SYSTEMS
sect2.para: Once an isolate has been identified as aFrancisella sp., supplemental tests can be used for additional characterization, including typing of species, subspecies, and strain. Glycerol fermentation and citrulline ureidase activity distinguish F. tularensis subsp. tularensis from F. tularensis subsp. holarctica (Table 2). Molecular methods including PCR and sequencing can type isolates at the levels of genus, species, subspecies (F. tularensis subsp. tularensis or F. tularensis subsp. holarctica), and subclade (e.g., F. tularensis subsp. tularensis subclades A1 and A2) (51, 88, 89). Whole-genome sequence-based typing shows improved resolution and is likely to be used more extensively in the future as next-generation sequencing technology becomes more readily available (90).

sect2.title: SEROLOGIC TESTS
sect2.para: A confirmatory diagnosis of tularemia can be established serologically by demonstrating a 4-fold change between titers of specific antibody toF. tularensis antigen in acute- and convalescent-phase sera (51). Serological assays do not distinguish between F. tularensis subsp. tularensis and F. tularensis subsp. holarctica. A single positive antibody titer is a presumptive diagnosis of tularemia. As antibody responses to F. tularensis generally require 10 to 20 days to develop postinfection, serologic testing is of limited use in clinical management of patients with acute illness. Immunoglobulin M (IgM), IgA, and IgG antibodies may appear simultaneously. Antibodies to F. tularensis can persist for more than 10 years, including IgM responses, which are therefore not indicative of early or recent infection (91).

Agglutination testing, by either the tube agglutination or the microagglutination method, is a standard serological test for determining the presence of antibodies in tularemia (51, 91). Formalin-killed antigen is commercially available and is also prepared within reference laboratories worldwide. A single specimen with a tube agglutination titer of ≥1:160 or a microagglutination titer of ≥1:128 is considered positive. Formalin-killed F. tularensis whole-cell antigen may display low-level cross-reactivity with Brucella antibodies. False-positive results due to antigenic cross-reaction are more common at titers <1:40 (92). No cross-reactivity of F. novicida or F. philomiragia sera with killed F. tularensis cells has been observed (91).

Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assays (ELISAs) can also be used for serological diagnosis of tularemia (91). The lipopolysaccharide and/or outer membrane fraction is the primary ELISA antigen used in test applications. Antibody responses are usually detected earlier by ELISA compared to agglutination tests. The higher sensitivity of anti-F. tularensis ELISAs, however, can result in lower specificity as compared to microagglutination (cutoff, >1:80) (93).

sect2.title: ANTIMICROBIAL SUSCEPTIBILITIES
sect2.para: F. tularensis infections are treatable with antibiotics. Antibiotics used to treat tularemia include streptomycin, gentamicin, doxycycline, and ciprofloxacin. For more information see https://www.cdc.gov/tularemia/clinicians/index.html. All naturally occurring isolates of F. tularensis to date have been susceptible to aminoglycosides, tetracyclines, and fluoroquinolones (51, 94). The risk for development of antibiotic resistance in clinical disease is low, as tularemia is an end-stage disease and is not transmitted from person to person (51). Treatment failures in tularemia patients correlate with a delay in the initiation of antibiotics, rather than development of resistance (66, 95). Lymph node suppuration, which is nonresponsive to all classes of antibiotics, can develop in these cases, and recovery times can be greater than 70 days (95).

β-Lactam antibiotics are not used for treatment of tularemia, asF. tularensis strains produce a class A β-lactamase, FTU-1 (96). β-Lactam resistance in F. tularensis appears to be limited to penicillins; in vitro MIC determinations indicate that FTU-1 does not confer resistance to other β-lactams, including first- and second-generation cephalosporins (96). Although third-generation cephalosporins have been shown to be active against F. tularensis in vitro, clinical experience indicates that ceftriaxone is not effective for treatment of tularemia (97). F. tularensis subsp. holarctica strains from Central and Eastern Europe and Asia are naturally resistant to erythromycin and other macrolides (98).

Antimicrobial susceptibility testing ofF. tularensis is not performed in clinical microbiology laboratories because of safety concerns and because resistance to antibiotics used for clinical treatment of tularemia has never been reported (94). The Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) has published interpretative criteria and quality control limits for broth microdilution of F. tularensis using cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton medium supplemented with 2% defined growth supplement (99).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Isolation of a very tiny Gram-negative bacterium that grows slowly, shows fastidious growth characteristics, and is oxidase negative, weakly catalase positive, urease negative, X (hemin)/V (NAD) or satellite negative, and β-lactamase positive should be strongly suspected asF. tularensis and referred to a reference laboratory (LRN reference laboratories in the United States) (51). Confirmation of F. tularensis infections includes (i) recovery of an isolate and identification as F. tularensis and/or (ii) a 4-fold difference in titers in acute- and convalescent-phase serum samples, with one of the paired samples having a positive titer. A positive test result for a primary clinical specimen using antigen or molecular detection methods, including DFA staining, immunohistochemical staining, or NAAT, provides only a presumptive diagnosis of F. tularensis. A single positive serum sample is also considered presumptive for tularemia. Culture provides a conclusive diagnosis of infection and should be attempted using appropriate biosafety measures. Serology is commonly used for laboratory confirmation of F. tularensis infection, due to the organism’s slow growth and fastidious nature. Patients’ symptoms must be taken into account to ensure that a laboratory diagnosis of tularemia is compatible with the clinical picture. Any Francisella sp. identification by nucleic acid detection (PCR, shotgun metagenomics, 16S rRNA gene sequencing) or automated systems (e.g., MALDI-TOF MS, biochemical systems) should be referred to reference laboratories (LRN reference laboratories in the United States) for F. tularensis-specific testing.

In the United States, tularemia is a nationally notifiable disease andF. tularensis is classified as a Tier 1 select agent. Identification of a bacterial select agent requires isolation of the organism in culture and confirmatory testing. Laboratories identifying an organism as F. tularensis are required to report this finding to the Select Agent Program within 24 hours and submit a Form 4 within 7 calendar days. Report forms, contact information, laboratory registration information, and pertinent citations of the U.S. Federal Code may be found at http://www.selectagents.gov. F. tularensis is also a notifiable disease in most European countries, and information is collected by the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control (30, 36).

OtherFrancisella species, particularly F. novicida, may be confused with F. tularensis in laboratory testing. Diagnosis of these organisms is challenging due to their rarity and their similarity to F. tularensis. Clinical laboratories are encouraged to consult reference laboratories if a Francisella species is suspected.
The findings and conclusions in this report are those of the authors and do not necessarily represent the official position of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
